item.title: Trump Threatens Canada Over Business Jet Dispute
item.description: The president said he would restrict the use of Canadian-built aircraft and impose a 50 percent tariff on them until the dispute was resolved.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi, Ian Austen and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: A SkyWest Airlines airplane landing at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport in Dallas in 2023. SkyWest has the most Canadian-built aircraft of any operator.

item.title: Trump Sues I.R.S. Over Tax Data Leak, Demanding $10 Billion
item.description: The president charged that the I.R.S. and the Treasury Department had failed to prevent a former I.R.S. contractor from gaining access to documents shared with news outlets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Internal Revenue Service office building in Washington last year.

item.title: Newsom Files Civil Rights Complaint Against Dr. Oz Over Fraud Video
item.description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, a top federal health official, posted a video that accuses Armenian Americans in California of health care fraud.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, speaking at the White House earlier this month.

item.title: War Threats and Ambiguous Evidence: Trump Again Confronts Iran
item.description: There is little sign that Iran has made significant progress in reconstituting its nuclear program, leaving questions about the timing and motive behind potential plans for further attacks.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little has happened in the past six months to indicate that Iran has made significant strides toward rebuilding its capacity to enrich nuclear fuel and fashion a nuclear warhead.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force Near Iran
item.description: President Trump has not authorized military action in Iran, but the U.S. has built up its presence in the region in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Eric Schmitt, Ashley Cai and Daniel Wood
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Did Trump Really Give Nicki Minaj a $1 Million ‘Gold Card’ Visa?
item.description: “Gold Trump card free of charge,” the rapper wrote on social media. But the White House says it’s not what it seems.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rapper Nicki Minaj greeting President Trump during an event in Washington on Wednesday. She is originally from Trinidad and Tobago and grew up in Queens.

item.title: Trump Weighs New Military Options Against Iran
item.description: The plans being weighed by the president go beyond those he considered weeks ago amid widespread protests against Iran’s government.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The options go beyond the proposals that Mr. Trump was considering two weeks ago as a means of following through on his promise to stop the killing of protesters by Iranian government security forces and affiliated militias.

item.title: Brendan Banfield Denies Plot in Double Murder Trial, Calling Accusations ‘Crazy’
item.description: Brendan Banfield rebuffed claims that he had made an elaborate plan for the killings with the family’s au pair, with whom he had an affair.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Brendan Banfield arriving to court in his double murder trial in Fairfax, Va., earlier this month.

item.title: Video Shows Bovino’s Orders to Immigration Agents in L.A. Raids
item.description: The Border Patrol commander gave agents wide latitude to arrest people as immigration raids began last summer. Similar tactics were later used in other cities.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: What Domestic Terrorism Means, and Doesn’t
item.description: The Trump administration has called the Minneapolis shooting victims “domestic terrorists.” Our criminal justice reporter Jonah E. Bromwich explains what that term actually means.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, Gilad Thaler, Sutton Raphael and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Minnesota State Senate Fields Testimony on ICE Violence in Twin Cities
item.description: In an hourslong hearing, lawmakers heard stories of the use of racial profiling and aggressive tactics against state residents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstration against ICE outside the State Capitol in St. Paul, Minn., earlier this month.

item.title: What to Know About Anti-ICE Protests This Weekend
item.description: Organizers are trying to build on the momentum of a strike last week that brought thousands into the streets in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators braved freezing temperatures to protest the immigration crackdown.

item.title: Map: Where ICE Has Had Access to Minnesota Jails and Prisons
item.description: About 30 percent of the people ICE detained in Minnesota last year were turned over by local jails and prisons, a New York Times analysis of federal data shows, but that number is a lower share than in 39 other states.
item.dc:creator: Albert Sun

item.title: Michael Beck, 65, Dies; First to Report Symptoms of ‘Havana Syndrome’
item.description: As an employee with the N.S.A., he claimed he was exposed to a direct-energy device that led to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease at the age of 45.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Katherine Frey/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Beck in 2017. He said he began experiencing debilitating symptoms of Havana Syndrome much earlier than many other federal employees.

item.title: Trump Says Putin Agreed to a Weeklong Pause in Attacks Amid Extreme Cold
item.description: Russia has left thousands of apartment buildings in Kyiv without heat in recent weeks, in a campaign that has appeared aimed at breaking Ukraine’s morale.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Sergei Gapon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A building in Kyiv protected by sandbags on Thursday.

item.title: How Trump’s 2020 Election Claims Have Been Debunked Again and Again
item.description: The Trump administration has recently escalated its efforts to prove widespread voter fraud in 2020. Election officials and top Republicans have repeatedly said these claims are baseless.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered outside the Supreme Court for a “Stop the Steal” protest in early December 2020.

item.title: Educator Who Read ‘I Need a New Butt!’ to Students Wins Job Back in Court
item.description: An appellate court ruled that the firing of the former assistant principal of an elementary school in Mississippi in 2022 had been “arbitrary and capricious.”
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Barbara Gauntt/The Clarion-Ledger, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Toby Price, a former assistant principal at an elementary school in Mississippi, was fired for reading “I need a new butt!” by Dawn McMillan to second-grade students.

item.title: One Solution for Too Many A’s? Harvard Considers Giving A+ Grades.
item.description: Harvard University has been trying to cut back how many A grades professors give. Now, 53 percent of grades are A’s, down from 60 percent.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Patrick Schiltz, an Ethicist, Is the Minnesota Judge Blasting ICE
item.description: Judge Patrick Schiltz, an appointee of George W. Bush, became an unlikely critic of the Trump administration’s tactics in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota
item.media:description: Chief Judge Patrick J. Schiltz has shown increasing frustration and anger with the Trump administration and its tactics in court.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds TPS Protections for Venezuelans in the U.S.
item.description: The Trump administration has sought to end Temporary Protected Status for more than a million people from troubled nations. About 600,000 are from Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, at the White House in Washington, D.C., this month.

item.title: Groups Back Larson Challenger, Calling for Generational Change
item.description: Three outside political groups are backing Luke Bronin in his primary challenge to Representative John Larson, the 77-year-old Connecticut Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative John Larson, Democrat of Connecticut, last November. The 77-year-old is seeking a 15th term in office.

item.title: Trump Says He Only Appeared to Nod Off in Last Cabinet Meeting Because It Was ‘Boring’
item.description: Mr. Trump’s allies have strenuously insisted that he was alert and attentive at the meeting last month. The president said he had only closed his eyes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump held a meeting with his cabinet at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Democrats Reach Spending Deal With Trump, Seeking to Rein In ICE
item.description: Democrats and the White House agreed to fund the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while they negotiate restrictions on an immigration crackdown. Senators said they hoped to vote on the deal on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, began negotiations with President Trump late Wednesday to try to head off a government shutdown.

item.title: Man Accused of Squirting Ilhan Omar with Vinegar Is Charged With Assault
item.description: Ms. Omar was sprayed with liquid from a syringe as she spoke at a town hall and called for the resignation of Kristi Noem, who leads the Homeland Security Department.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthony J. Kazmierczak was accused of squirting Representative Ilhan Omar with a substance during a town hall in Minneapolis.

item.title: Democratic Governors Promise Accountability After Alex Pretti Killing
item.description: The chin-out rhetoric of Democratic governors about holding Trump administration officials responsible for violence in their cities may be more political than practicable.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners laid candles under posters of Renee Good and Alex Pretti Wednesday night near the site in Minneapolis where Mr. Pretti was killed.

item.title: Homan Calls for ‘Improvements’ to Minneapolis ICE Operation
item.description: The White House border czar said there are plans for a “drawdown” if his agents get access to jails in the state.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Homan said his agents have tried to behave professionally in a challenging environment.

item.title: Collins Took Credit for ICE Leaving Maine. Her Democratic Opponents Pounced.
item.description: Political maneuvering by the Democrats hoping to unseat Senator Susan Collins shifted into high gear with the news that ICE had ended its surge there.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Lewiston, Maine, on Saturday to protest Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s presence in the state.

item.title: Former Deputy Sean Grayson Sentenced to 20 Years in Sonya Massey Shooting
item.description: The deputy, Sean Grayson, was convicted of second-degree murder for killing Ms. Massey in 2024 at her home in Springfield, Ill., after she had called 911.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Mike Bailey
item.category: Grayson, Sean (Sangamon County, Ill, Police Officer)
item.media:credit: Scott Olson/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Rev. Al Sharpton spoke alongside relatives of Sonya Massey at a church in Chicago in 2024.

item.title: San Jose Mayor Matt Mahan Will Run for California Governor in 2026
item.description: Matt Mahan, a moderate Democrat who serves as mayor of San Jose, Calif., is entering the crowded race for California governor.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Lauren Segal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Mahan, the mayor of San Jose, Calif., has focused on reducing homelessness and crime. He has avoided attacking President Trump.

item.title: Texas Democrats Call for Release of Liam Ramos, 5-Year-Old Detained by ICE
item.description: Representative Joaquin Castro said Liam Conejo Ramos appeared lethargic during a visit by lawmakers to the facility where he and his father are being held. The pair was detained in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lina Fisher

item.title: Amy Klobuchar Announces Run for Minnesota Governor
item.description: The Democratic senator, who signaled her bid after Gov. Tim Walz said he wouldn’t run again, talked about moving past political divides in a video announcement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Amy Klobuchar’s campaign will test how Democrats can harness the deep anger over ICE’s tactics among their base without losing moderate voters who still support border enforcement.

item.title: Shirley Raines, 58, Who Gave L.A.’s Homeless Food and Makeovers, Dies
item.description: Her work feeding people and dyeing their hair through her nonprofit, Beauty 2 the Streetz, was known to millions online.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shirley Raines in Los Angeles in 2023.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Chelsia Rose Marcius, Clyde McGrady and Catie Edmondson

item.title: Maxim Naumov to Skate at 2026 Olympics After Parents’ Death in D.C. Plane Crash
item.description: After his parents died in the midair collision over Washington, D.C., a year ago, Maxim Naumov struggled to put on his skates. Now he will compete for the United States at the Milan-Cortina Games.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maxim Naumov after a performance in Washington, D.C., last year.

item.title: Justice Dept. Playbook in Minnesota: Investigate Foes, Protect Allies
item.description: The Trump Justice Department has often cast aside normal procedures intended to seek accountability in favor of pushing prosecutors and the F.B.I. to focus on critics of the immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi and her chief deputy, Todd Blanche, have so far resisted authorizing traditional civil rights investigations into any of the officers who killed Renee Good and Alex Pretti.

item.title: What We Learned After Tracking Every Lawsuit Challenging Trump’s Policies
item.description: President Trump’s agenda faced more than 600 lawsuits over the past year. In many cases, district court judges found his policies to be unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: A State Senate Race in Texas Offers Republicans a Warning
item.description: A State Senate runoff on Saturday in the Fort Worth suburbs will preview whether a backlash against conservative social policies will give Democrats a chance to gain.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Worth is in Texas’ Ninth District, which will hold a runoff election for the Texas Senate on Jan. 31.

item.title: TPS Expiration Under Trump Hits Haitian Workers in Critical Health Care Roles
item.description: Haitians are a vital source of employees for health care providers in many communities. The Trump administration is removing legal status next month for 330,000 of them.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vilbrun Dorsainvil said he fled Haiti in 2021 after he was threatened for speaking out about the government. He settled in Springfield, Ohio, which is home to a growing Haitian community.

item.title: She Protested a Book Ban. Oklahoma Revoked Her Teacher’s License.
item.description: Summer Boismier, a high school English teacher in Oklahoma, lost her teaching license after she protested a book ban. Now she is fighting to return to the classroom.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Nick Oxford
item.media:credit: Nick Oxford for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Oklahoma passed laws that pressured teachers to remove books on race, gender and sexuality from their classrooms, Summer Boismier refused.
